title: Logan Sterner stutter-steps Pen Argyl football past Wilson
text:
Complete Box Score » 
The stutter-step stood out. 
Of all the fine things Logan Sterner did on the football field Saturday, the stutter-step looked best of all. 
That’s high praise given what the Pen Argyl sophomore running back did at Alumni Stadium Saturday afternoon during the Green Knights’ 49-28 Homecoming Colonial League defeat of visiting Wilson (1-7). 
Sterner tied the Pen Argyl (1-7) single-game touchdown record by reaching the end zone of runs of 5, 6, 46, 73, and 28 yards. 
He ran for 263 yards on the day; given that his season totals entering the game were 201 rushing yards and 4 TDs, you’d have to say Sterner had a good day. 
“I have never had a day like this,” he said. 
But even amid the pileup of yards and big plays, that stutter-step was soooo sweet. 
It came in the third quarter with the Green Knights up 36-13 but in no way secure given the Warriors’ big-play capability. 
Pen Argyl had just stopped a promising Warrior drive when junior defensive back Nick Guerro leapt for an interception in the end zone. 
One play later, Sterner took a handoff left from his 27-yard line. Instead of charging blindly upfield into waiting defenders, he waited for his blocks to develop … with that textbook stutter-step. 
73 yards later, after showing off his speed, he was in the end zone for the fifth consecutive unanswered TD by the Green Knights, thanks to that stutter-step that froze the defense and allowed the holes to open up. 
It’s not a maneuver seen much in football any more, and to see it done so well warms the hearts of old-time gridiron fans -- but it still works. 
“Logan’s a really patient runner,” Pen Argyl coach Paul Reduzzi said. “He was great power and that burst of speed when he needs it.” 
Sterner said the running emphasis was the game plan all along. 
“All we worked on all week was our running game,” Sterner said. “We knew we needed to have a great game running this week and we wanted to run the ball right at Wilson. We really wanted this game, and we went out and played the way we wanted to.” 
Sterner has more than speed and that stutter-step. He sees the field well, has almost an empathic relationship with his blockers, and has the shifty kind of hips that drive defenders bonkers. And once he slips by a tackler, then comes that burst. 
And he can throw the ball, too, as his 61-yard TD pass to James Klinger on an option toss showed. 
Sterner delighted the Homecoming crowd, to be sure. 
And he delighted somebody very special, too. After the players had left the Pen Argyl locker room all smiling, Reduzzi explained why he felt so good for Sterner. 
“Logan’s mom has been having some health problems, and it’s been tough for his family,” the Pen Argyl coach said. “But she was able to be here today and see him do what he did today. It was important that she was here and Logan responded to it.” 
Hard to imagine a better response – or a better stutter-step – from Logan Sterner.
